Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Help.Tip: Invoke dialogue box to select an input parameter file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SELECT_PATH_OPEN
Invoke dialogue box to select an input parameter file
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Invoke dialogue box to select an input parameter file

Help.Tip: An input parameter file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PATH_OPEN
An input parameter file
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = Character
 An input parameter file in one of the supported formats.

Help.Tip: Press button to read a parameter file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - OPEN_IT
Press button to read a parameter file

Help.Tip: Invoke dialogue box to choose an output parameter file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SELECT_PATH_SAVE
Invoke dialogue box to choose an output parameter file
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Invoke dialogue box to select an output parameter file

Help.Tip: An output parameter file name
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PATH_SAVE
An output parameter file name
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = Character
 An output parameter file name

Help.Tip: Press button to save a parameter file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SAVE_IT
Press button to save a parameter file
 
 Will save the modeling parameters to the PATH_SAVE file
 in a format consistent  with the setting of SAVE_TYPE.
 Shell scripts will also be generated for several of the
 output types (E2D,I2D,I3D,A3D). If SAVE_TYPE=I3D a QC plot
 may pop up. Some directory setup may also occur depending
 upon the output type.

Help.Tip: Choose the format to use for the path_save file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SAVE_TYPE
Choose the format to use for the path_save file
 
 Default = A2D
 Allowed = A2D
 Allowed = E2D
 Allowed = I2D
 Allowed = I3D
 Allowed = A3D0
 Allowed = A3D
 Choose the format to use for the path_save file
 A2D and E2D are 2D acoustic and elastic modeling programs
 that use explicit finite difference operators. I2D targets a
 2D illumination program. I3D targets a SITI 3D illumination.
 A3D0 is a 3D acoustic exploding reflector program. A3D is an
 acoustic 3D shot modeling program.

Help.Tip: Starting shot for this job
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SHOT1
Starting shot for this job
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer>0
 Starting shot for this job.
 Used by E2D and I2D, I3D options.
 Model shots in the range shot1 to shot1+maxshots-1.

Help.Tip: Limit on the number of shots modeled per submitted job
Help.Text:
cpsmod - MAXSHOTS
Limit on the number of shots modeled per submitted job
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer>0
 Limit on the number of shots modeled per submitted job.
 Model shots in the range shot1 to shot1+maxshots-1.
 CPSMOD jobs that run A2D will model no more than maxshots shots.

Help.Tip: Skip shots
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SHOT_INC
Skip shots
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer>0
 Do evey SHOT_INC'th shot.
 Model shots shot1, shot1+shotinc, etc

Help.Tip: Limit on the number of jobs running simultaneously
Help.Text:
cpsmod - MAXJOBS
Limit on the number of jobs running simultaneously
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = <=100
 Limit on the number of jobs running simultaneously. This
 parameter is used if a project file is defined by PATH_PROJ.

Screen.title: Grid and Model Parameters
Screen.Label: Physical Model Use amod module here
OPT_ANISO=

ArraySet.label: TITLE_MOD OPT_MOD CONST_MOD DEPTH_MOD GRAD_MOD PATH_MOD

Screen.Label: VMIN=
VMAX=

X_TOT=
X_ORG=
X_INC=
X_HDR=
Y_TOT=
Y_ORG=
Y_INC=
Y_HDR=
Z_TOT=
Z_ORG=
Z_INC=
Z_MAX=
T_TOT=
T_ORG=
T_INC=
T_MAX=
UNITS
DTMAX=
GRIDMAX=
Boundary Conditions
TOP_BC=
SIDE_BC=
ABC_STYLE=
ABC_SWATH_SIZE=

Help.Tip: Velocity model file name.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - OPT_ANISO
Velocity model file name.
 
 Default = ISOTROPIC
 Allowed = ISOTROPIC    Isotropic time and depth migration.
 Allowed = ANISOTROPIC  Vertical anisotropic time and depth migration.
 Allowed = TILTED_BED   Tilted bed anisotropic depth migration.
 Allowed = ISOELASTIC   Vp, Vs, Denisty for E2D
 Allowed = ANIELASTIC   Vp, Vs, Denisty, epsilon, delta for E2D

Help.Tip: Title of model coefficient.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - TITLE_MOD
Title of model coefficient.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character

Help.Tip: How each model coefficient is defined.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - OPT_MOD
How each model coefficient is defined.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character

Help.Tip: Constant value for model coeffieicnt at depth DEPTH_MOD.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - CONST_MOD
Constant value for model coeffieicnt at depth DEPTH_MOD.
 
 Default = 2000.
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Depth from which graident is measured.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - DEPTH_MOD
Depth from which graident is measured.
 
 Default = 0.
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Gradient for mdoel coefficient.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - GRAD_MOD
Gradient for mdoel coefficient.
 
 Default = 0.
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Name of model coefficient file.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PATH_MOD
Name of model coefficient file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 The X_SIN coefficient is the sine of the anisotropic coefficient dip angle
 projected into the x,z plane.
 The Y_SIN coefficient is the sine of the anisotropic coefficient dip angle
 projected into the y,z plane.
 For a horizontal geometry x_sin = y_sin = 0.
 For a 30 degree dip from the horizontal in the x direction, x_sin = .5
 For a 45 degree dip from the horizontal in the x direction, x_sin = .7071
 The true dip of the anisotropic coefficient from the z axis is:
 asin ( sqrt ( 1. - x_sin**2 - y_sin**2 ) )
 If any PATH_MOD entry is other than NONE or CONST_MOD IS not equal to 0.
 AMOD assumes an anisotropic model.
 Then PATH_MOD(1) is the vZ values and the group velocity is
 1/v(a)**2 = cos(a)**2/vz**2 + sin(a)**2/vx**2 * (1 + 2*ETA*cos(a)**2 )
 If TYPE_TABLE_CALC = TIME, PATH_MOD(1) is assumed to be the stacking velocity.
 Otherwise, PATH_MOD(1) is assumed to be the vertical interval velocity.
 If PATH_MOD(2) is NONE the steep dip anisotropic coefficient is CONST_MOD

Help.Tip: Min velocity to use for stability-accuracy limit estimates
Help.Text:
cpsmod - VMIN
Min velocity to use for stability-accuracy limit estimates
 
 Default = 1500
 Allowed = REAL>0
 Min velocity to use for DTMAX and GRIDMAX estimate

Help.Tip: Max velocity to use for stability-accuracy limit estimates
Help.Text:
cpsmod - VMAX
Max velocity to use for stability-accuracy limit estimates
 
 Default = 4500
 Allowed = REAL>0
 Max velocity to use for DTMAX and GRIDMAX estimate

Help.Tip: Number of x grid points
Help.Text:
cpsmod - X_TOT
Number of x grid points
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer > 0
 Number of x grid points.
 A2D sets this from the recording geometry.

Help.Tip: The X origin
Help.Text:
cpsmod - X_ORG
The X origin
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = Real
 The computational X origin. Use grid units if header 7-8 are used and
 physical units if header 17-18 are specified. This parameter needs
 to be consistent with the velocity model.
 For A2D the origin will be determined by the shot
 location and receiver pattern and x_org is ignored.

Help.Tip: Computational bin size in the x direction
Help.Text:
cpsmod - X_INC
Computational bin size in the x direction
 
 Default = 10.0
 Allowed = Real>0
 Computational grid size in x direction. Use grid units
 if header 7-8 are used. Use physical units if header
 17-18 are specified.

Help.Tip: CPS header consistent with spatial x-coordinates
Help.Text:
cpsmod - X_HDR
CPS header consistent with spatial x-coordinates
 
 Default = 7
 Allowed =
 CPS header consistent with spatial x-coordinates. If
 header 7 or 8 is used the x and y coordinates are in
 grid units and the coordinates will be scaled by the grid
 transform during computation.

Help.Tip: number of y grid pointes
Help.Text:
cpsmod - Y_TOT
number of y grid pointes
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer > 0
 Number of y grid points in computational window

Help.Tip: Min y location of the computational window
Help.Text:
cpsmod - Y_ORG
Min y location of the computational window
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 The computational Y origin. Use grid units if header 7-8 are used and
 physical units if header 17-18 are specified. This parameter needs
 to be consistent with the velocity model.

Help.Tip: Computational grid size in y direction
Help.Text:
cpsmod - Y_INC
Computational grid size in y direction
 
 Default = 10.0
 Allowed = real>0
 Computational grid size in y direction

Help.Tip: CPS header consistent with spatial y-coordinates
Help.Text:
cpsmod - Y_HDR
CPS header consistent with spatial y-coordinates
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed =
 CPS header consistent with spatial y-coordinates. If
 header 7 or 8 is used the x and y coordinates will
 be scaled by the grid transform during computation

Help.Tip: Number of depth points in the computational grid
Help.Text:
cpsmod - Z_TOT
Number of depth points in the computational grid
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer > 0
 Number of depth points in the computational grid.

Help.Tip: Origin of the depth axis.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - Z_ORG
Origin of the depth axis.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = Real
 Origin of the z or depth axis. The units are assumed to be the
 same as the units specified by project_data.

Help.Tip: Computational grid size in z direction
Help.Text:
cpsmod - Z_INC
Computational grid size in z direction
 
 Default = 8.0
 Allowed = Real > 0
 Computational grid size in z direction.
 The units are assumed to be the same as the units
 specified by project_data.

Help.Tip: Maximum depth of modeling window
Help.Text:
cpsmod - Z_MAX
Maximum depth of modeling window
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed =
 Maximum depth of modeling window.

Help.Tip: Total number of time steps
Help.Text:
cpsmod - T_TOT
Total number of time steps
 
 Default = 100
 Allowed = Integer > 0
 Total number of time step. This is computed
 from T_MAX and T_INC. T_TOT = T_MAX/T_INC + 1

Help.Tip: Start time in sec - not used
Help.Text:
cpsmod - T_ORG
Start time in sec - not used
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Start time in sec - not used

Help.Tip: Computational time step in seconds
Help.Text:
cpsmod - T_INC
Computational time step in seconds
 
 Default =
 Allowed = Positive
 Computational time step in seconds.

Help.Tip: Maximum elapsed time to model in sec
Help.Text:
cpsmod - T_MAX
Maximum elapsed time to model in sec
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed =
 Maximum elapsed time to model in sec

Help.Tip: Value for survey units - informative
Help.Text:
cpsmod - UNITS
Value for survey units - informative
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Max allowed time step for FD modeling
Help.Text:
cpsmod - DTMAX
Max allowed time step for FD modeling
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Max allowed time step limit to use with finite difference modeling options.
 Estimate = 0.5*dx/vmax

Help.Tip: Max recomended computational bin size
Help.Text:
cpsmod - GRIDMAX
Max recomended computational bin size
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Max allowed computational bin size. vmin/(f*fmax)

Help.Tip: Boundary condition to apply at the top surface
Help.Text:
cpsmod - TOP_BC
Boundary condition to apply at the top surface
 
 Default = DIRICHLET
 Allowed = DIRICHLET
 Allowed = ABSORB
 Allowed = NEUMAN
 Dirichlet sets P=0 at z=0. Neuman implies normal derivative of P
 vanishes at z=0. A paraxial BC is applied at the top
 if ABSORP is chosen.

Help.Tip: Boundary condition to apply at the side surfaces
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SIDE_BC
Boundary condition to apply at the side surfaces
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Type of absorbing BC to apply
Help.Text:
cpsmod - ABC_STYLE
Type of absorbing BC to apply
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Size of absorbing BC swath in grid nodes
Help.Text:
cpsmod - ABC_SWATH_SIZE
Size of absorbing BC swath in grid nodes
 
 Default = 10
 Allowed =
 If the b.c. is set to ABSORB then the wave field will be
 damped over this many grid nodes.

Help.Tip: Output trace sample rate(sec) for VSP and HSP files
Help.Text:
cpsmod - DT_OUT
Output trace sample rate(sec) for VSP and HSP files
 
 Default = 0.004
 Allowed = Real > T_INC
 Output trace sample rate(sec) for VSP and HSP files.
 Defaults to the job_data sample rate. This is only relevant
 for forward fd modeling options.

Help.Tip: Specify a directory for recording data
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SELECT_PATH_REC
Specify a directory for recording data
 
 Default =
 Allowed = 104 character
 Invoke a dialogue to choose an output directory.

Help.Tip: Specify a directory for recording output
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PATH_REC
Specify a directory for recording output
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed =
 Specify a directory for recording output. This is
 where hsp, vsp and snapshot files will be saved.
 A2D jobs will store trace files in this directory.
 E2D jobs will store output to subdirectories of
 path_rec.
 I3D will use this as the parent directory for output.

Help.Tip: Choose a method for specifying geophone locations
Help.Text:
cpsmod - HSP_OPT
Choose a method for specifying geophone locations
 
 Default = GRID
 Allowed = GRID
 Allowed = FILE
 HSP geophone coordinates can be specified from a FILE, or
 by the HSP GRID parameters. The HSP GRID parameters put
 the HSP phones on a regular constant depth grid.

Help.Tip: Specify a columnated ascii file with HSP X Y Z locations
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SELECT_HSP_LOC
Specify a columnated ascii file with HSP X Y Z locations
 
 Default =
 Allowed = 104 CHARACTER
 Invoke a file selection dialogue

Help.Tip: Specify a columnated ascii file with HSP X Y Z locations
Help.Text:
cpsmod - HSP_LOC
Specify a columnated ascii file with HSP X Y Z locations
 
 Default =
 Allowed = 104 CHARACTER
 Specify a columnated ascii file with HSP X Y Z locations.
 Blank lines and lines starting with # are ignored

Help.Tip: Number of cables per shot to record
Help.Text:
cpsmod - NCABLE
Number of cables per shot to record
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer>=1
  Number of cables to record per shot. The number
  of geophones recorded per shot will be ncable*hsp_num.

Help.Tip: Distance between cables within a streamer
Help.Text:
cpsmod - CABLESPACING
Distance between cables within a streamer
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = Real>=0
 Distance between cables within a streamer.

Help.Tip: Specify a trace file name for recording seismic traces
Help.Text:
cpsmod - HSP_NAME
Specify a trace file name for recording seismic traces
 
 Default =
 Allowed = 32 Character
 Specify a trace file name for recording seismic traces. This
 is the name without a path or suffix. The hsp file name will be
 a catenation of path_rec + hsp_name. The exact name is sensitive
 the output style. The hsp file is stored in the SU file format for
 A2D and in ! segy format for E2D. I3D will output a segy file.

Help.Tip: Z location of the geophones
Help.Text:
cpsmod - HSP_DEP
Z location of the geophones
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = Real>0
 Z location of the geophones. Is forced to be a multiple
 of Z_INC.

Help.Tip: Number of geophones to record per cable
Help.Text:
cpsmod - HSP_NUM
Number of geophones to record per cable
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = Integer>=0
  Number of geophones to record per cable. The number
  of geophones recorded will be ncable*hsp_num. Less than 10000

Help.Tip: Geophone starting x position relative to source
Help.Text:
cpsmod - HSP_XORG
Geophone starting x position relative to source
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = REAL
 First geophone starting x position. This is the offset
 relative to the shot location.

Help.Tip: Geophone starting y position relative to source
Help.Text:
cpsmod - HSP_YORG
Geophone starting y position relative to source
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = REAL
 First geophone starting y position. This is the offset
 relative to the shot location.

Help.Tip: Geophone bin spacing in x direction
Help.Text:
cpsmod - HSP_XINC
Geophone bin spacing in x direction
 
 Default = 10.0
 Allowed = REAL
 Geophone bin spacing in x direction

Help.Tip: Geophone bin spacing in y direction
Help.Text:
cpsmod - HSP_YINC
Geophone bin spacing in y direction
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = REAL
 Geophone bin spacing in y direction

Help.Tip: Pad grid to left of shot and geophone locations
Help.Text:
cpsmod - L_PAD
Pad grid to left of shot and geophone locations
 
 Default = 40
 Allowed = Integer>=0
 Pad grid to left of shot and geophone locations.
 Specify as an integer number of grid nodes.

Help.Tip: Pad grid to right of shot and geophone locations
Help.Text:
cpsmod - R_PAD
Pad grid to right of shot and geophone locations
 
 Default = 40
 Allowed = Integer>=0
 Pad grid to right of shot and geophone locations.
 Specify as an integer number of grid nodes.

Help.Tip: Computational window in the cross cable direction
Help.Text:
cpsmod - IL_AP
Computational window in the cross cable direction
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real>0
 Perform computatiuon in a window at least this big in the
 x-line or cross-cable direction. Specify in survey units
 of meters or feet.

Help.Tip: Computational window in the in line direction
Help.Text:
cpsmod - XL_AP
Computational window in the in line direction
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real>0
 Perform computatiuon in a window at least this big in the
 in-line or cable direction. Will be ignored for 2D
 modeling. Specify in survey units of meters or feet.

Help.Tip: Choose a method for specifying geophone locations
Help.Text:
cpsmod - VSP_OPT
Choose a method for specifying geophone locations
 
 Default = GRID
 Allowed = GRID
 Allowed = FILE
 VSP geophone coordinates can be specified from a FILE, or
 by the VSP GRID parameters. The VSP GRID parameters put
 the VSP phones on a regular grid at a fixed X-Y position.

Help.Tip: Specify a columnated ascii file with VSP X Y Z locations
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SELECT_VSP_LOC
Specify a columnated ascii file with VSP X Y Z locations
 
 Default =
 Allowed = 104 CHARACTER
 Invoke a file selection dialogue

Help.Tip: Specify a columnated ascii file with VSP X Y Z locations
Help.Text:
cpsmod - VSP_LOC
Specify a columnated ascii file with VSP X Y Z locations
 
 Default =
 Allowed = 104 CHARACTER
 Specify a columnated ascii file with VSP X Y Z locations
 Blank lines and lines starting with # are ignored

Help.Tip: Name of vsp file without path
Help.Text:
cpsmod - VSP_NAME
Name of vsp file without path
 
 Default =
 Allowed = 32 character
 Name of vsp file without path.
 for A2D - vsp file = path_rec/vsp_name.trc
 for E2D - vsp file = path_rec/shot#/vsp_name.trc

Help.Tip: Depth of first VSP geophone
Help.Text:
cpsmod - VSP_DEP
Depth of first VSP geophone
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = Real
 Depth of first VSP geophone. This value
 will be forced onto the nearest Z-grid point.

Help.Tip: Number of VSP geophones to record
Help.Text:
cpsmod - VSP_NUM
Number of VSP geophones to record
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = Integer between 0 and Z_TOT
 Number of VSP geophones to record.

Help.Tip: X Location of the VSP geophones
Help.Text:
cpsmod - VSP_XORG
X Location of the VSP geophones
 
 Default =
 Allowed = Real
 X Location of the VSP geophones.
 This is absolute X and not relative to the shot location.

Help.Tip: Y Location of the VSP geophones
Help.Text:
cpsmod - VSP_YORG
Y Location of the VSP geophones
 
 Default =
 Allowed = Real
 Y Location of the VSP geophones
 This is absolute Y and not relative to the shot location.

Help.Tip: Depth increment between VSP geophones
Help.Text:
cpsmod - VSP_INC
Depth increment between VSP geophones
 
 Default = 10.0
 Allowed = Real
 Depth increment between VSP geophones. The increment
 will be forced to be a multiple of Z_INC

Help.Tip: Name of snapshot file without path_rec
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SNAP_NAME
Name of snapshot file without path_rec
 
 Default =
 Allowed = 32 character
 Name of snapshot file without path. The full snapshot
 file name = a catenation of path_rec + snap_name +
 shot x location + "vo"

Help.Tip: Time(ms) of the first snapshot
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SNAP_START
Time(ms) of the first snapshot
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = Integer
 Time(ms) of the first snapshot.

Help.Tip: Time(ms) between snapshots
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SNAP_DT
Time(ms) between snapshots
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = Integer
 A snapshot will be recorded every SNAP_DT ms
 Set SNAP_DT<=0 for no snapshots

Help.Tip: Max time(ms) of the last snapshot
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SNAP_STOP
Max time(ms) of the last snapshot
 
 Default = 100000
 Allowed = Integer
 Will not record a snapshot after time=snap_stop.
 Specify time in units of ms.

Help.Tip: Decimate snapshot wavefield
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SNAP_DECX
Decimate snapshot wavefield
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer
 Will resord every nth point in the x direction

Help.Tip: Decimate snapshot wavefield
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SNAP_DECY
Decimate snapshot wavefield
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer
 Will record every nth point in the y direction

Help.Tip: Choose how source coordinates are specified
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SRC_SPEC
Choose how source coordinates are specified
 
 Default = SKIP
 Allowed = SKIP
 Allowed = INFO
 Choose how source coordinates are specified. Can
 use either a regular skip pattern, or one can get
 coordinates from an fxinfo file. If SRC_SPEC=SKIP
 then SRC_NUM  shots are modeled starting at SRC_XORG
 and incrementing by SRC_XINC. If SRC_SPEC=INFO the
 shot locations are set from the PATH_INFO file. The
 path_info and path_proj values are ignored when the
 SKIP option is chosen

Help.Tip: Dialogue to select a project file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SELECT_PATH_PROJ
Dialogue to select a project file
 
 Default =
 Allowed = Character
 Dialogue to select an optional project file name.

Help.Tip: Specify a project file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PATH_PROJ
Specify a project file
 
 Default =
 Allowed = Character
 Specify an optional project file. The key components
 of a project file are an fxinfo file list, and a task list file.
 The task file is used to coordinate the work done by batch
 parallel jobs. In the case of CPSMOD the tasks are either the shot
 locations or an I3D sub-domain to be modeled. Use a project file if
 you want to use mutiple jobs to generate multiple synthetic shots, or
 if a large I3D project is broken into sub-domains. If the project
 file points to an fxinfo list, the input shot positions will be
 obtained from the info file. An info file is a summary of the
 gathers in one or more seismic files(e.g. the shot locations).
 The task file keeps track of the status of work or "tasks".
 If there is no info list the shot locations are determined by
 the pattern given by src_num, src_xorg, src_xinc.

Help.Tip: Informative - itask file name setting for project
Help.Text:
cpsmod - TSKFILE
Informative - itask file name setting for project
 
 Default =
 Allowed = Character
 This is the file name used when the init_tasks button is activated.

Help.Tip: Press button to save a project file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - INIT_PROJ
Press button to save a project file
 
 Write out a project file. Be careful that you do
 not overwrite a project file that is in use. See
 the help for path_proj for the details.

Help.Tip: Dialogue to select an input fxinfo file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SELECT_PATH_INFO
Dialogue to select an input fxinfo file
 
 Default =
 Allowed = Character
 Dialogue to select an input fxinfo file. The fxinfo file will be
 used to determine the shot locations if SRC_SPEC=INFO.

Help.Tip: Specify an fxinfo file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PATH_INFO
Specify an fxinfo file
 
 Default =
 Allowed = Character
 Specify an optional fxinfo file. The fxinfo file will be
 used to determine the shot locations if SRC_SPEC=INFO. This field
 will be set by the project file if a name of an existing
 project file is specified for PATH_PROJ. If no path_info
 is specified the shot locations are determined by
 src_num, src_xorg, and src_xinc.

Help.Tip: Press button to save a task file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - INIT_TASKS
Press button to save a task file
 
 A task file will be generated if there is an project file
 specified. Be careful not to overwrite a task file
 that is being used by a project with active jobs. The project
 file is also written. A task file contains a work list.
 i.e. a list of shots or a list of brick sub-domains.

Help.Tip: Number of shots in one shot line
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SHOTS_PER_LINE
Number of shots in one shot line
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = >=0
 The number of shots in one shot line. If SRC_SPEC=SKIP then
 the user sets this. If SRC_SPEC=INFO and PATH_INFO
 is set, the value is obtained from the path_info file.

Help.Tip: Number of shot lines to model
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SHOT_LINES
Number of shot lines to model
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = >=1
 The number of shot lines to model. If SRC_SPEC=SKIP then
 the user sets this. If SRC_SPEC=INFO and PATH_INFO
 is set, the value is obtained from the path_info file.

Help.Tip: The total number of shots to model
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SRC_NUM
The total number of shots to model
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = >=0
 The total number of shots to model.
 If SRC_SPEC=SKIP then the value is limited by
 src_num <= shots_per_line x shot_lines.
 If SRC_SPEC=INFO and PATH_INFO is set, the value is
 obtained from the path_info file.
 The number of shots modeled within a job can be modified
 by the maxshots parameter.

Help.Tip: Physical distance between shot lines
Help.Text:
cpsmod - LINE_SPACING
Physical distance between shot lines
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = >=0
 The physical distance between sequential shot lines.  In units
 of Feet or Meters consistent with survey units. Normally this
 should be an integer multiple of the x or y bin width that is
 used to define the grid transform.

Help.Tip: Shot line angle wrt E
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SRC_THETA
Shot line angle wrt E
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = >=0
 Shot line angle wrt E

Help.Tip: Physical distance between sequential shots
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SRC_DELTA
Physical distance between sequential shots
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = >=0
 The physical distance between sequential shots.
  In units survey units of Feet or Meters.

Help.Tip: Place sources at this depth
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SRC_DEP
Place sources at this depth
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = Real
 Place sources at this depth. Will be forced to be
 a multiple of Z_INC. Units should be consistent
 with the survey UNITS field of PROJECT_DATA.

Help.Tip: First shot x location
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SRC_XORG
First shot x location
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed =
 The x location of the first shot. The value is in grid units if
 x_hdr=7 or in phyical distance if x_hdr=17.

Help.Tip: Change in x coordinate between sequential shots
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SRC_XINC
Change in x coordinate between sequential shots
 
 Default = 10.0
 Allowed = REAL
 Change in x coordinate between sequential shots. If src_spec
 = INFO this is set from the info file and it represents
 an average shot spacing, not the actual shot spacing which
 may be variable. It is forced to be a multiple of x_inc.

Help.Tip: First shot y location
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SRC_YORG
First shot y location
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed =
 The y location of the first shot. The value is in grid units if
 y_hdr=8 or in phyical distance if y_hdr=18.

Help.Tip: Change in y coordinate between sequential shots
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SRC_YINC
Change in y coordinate between sequential shots
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = REAL
 Change in y coordinate between sequential shots. If src_spec
 is = INFO this is set from the info file and it represents
 an average shot spacing, not the actual shot spacing which
 may be variable.

Help.Tip: Invoke dialogue to choose a source wavelet file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SELECT_PATH_SRC
Invoke dialogue to choose a source wavelet file
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Invoke dialogue to choose a source wavelet file

Help.Tip: A source wavelet file
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PATH_SRC
A source wavelet file
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 A source wavelet file

Help.Tip: Min frequency of source in HZ
Help.Text:
cpsmod - FMIN
Min frequency of source in HZ
 
 Default = 4
 Allowed = REAL
 Min frequency of source in HZ

Help.Tip: Max frequency of source in HZ
Help.Text:
cpsmod - FMAX
Max frequency of source in HZ
 
 Default = 40
 Allowed = REAL
 Max frequency of source in HZ

Help.Tip: Peak frequency of the source wavelet
Help.Text:
cpsmod - FPEAK
Peak frequency of the source wavelet
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Peak frequency of the source wavelet.
 Used by I3D, I2D, A2D

Help.Tip: Press button to plot sources
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PLOTIT
Press button to plot sources
 
 plot

Screen.title: Domain Decomposition
Screen.Label: Control Spatial Decomposition for Parallel 3D Jobs +++
BRICK
BRICK_SAVE
NX_BRICKS=
BX_OVRLP=
BX_SIZ=
NY_BRICKS=
BY_OVRLP=
BY_SIZ=
NZ_BRICKS=
BZ_OVRLP=
BZ_SIZ=

Help.Tip: Number of sub-blocks in along the X axis
Help.Text:
cpsmod - BRICK
Number of sub-blocks in along the X axis
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES|NO
 Activate or deactivate domain decomposition

Help.Tip: Save files with brick information
Help.Text:
cpsmod - BRICK_SAVE
Save files with brick information
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES|NO
 Will save files with information that can be plotted with Gocad
 Boundaries of brick sub-domains and shot locations belonging to the
 sub-domains.

Help.Tip: Number of sub-blocks in along the X axis
Help.Text:
cpsmod - NX_BRICKS
Number of sub-blocks in along the X axis
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer>=1
 The brick parameters allow the user to do a spatial domain decomposition of
 the calculation. The calculaion for modeling or illumination is broken
 into nx_bricks sub-domains along the X axis.

Help.Tip: Number of grid points that overlap along the X axis
Help.Text:
cpsmod - BX_OVRLP
Number of grid points that overlap along the X axis
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = Integer>=0
 The brick parameters allow the user to do a spatial domain decomposition of
 the calculation. The parameter nx_ovrlp controls the overlap between
 adjacent spatial block along the X axis.
 This parameter is relevant to I3D only.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of grid points for a X axis block
Help.Text:
cpsmod - BX_SIZ
Maximum number of grid points for a X axis block
 
 Default = x_tot
 Allowed = Integer>0
 The brick parameters allow the user to do a spatial domain decomposition of
 the calculation. The parameter nx_siz indicates the maximum number of grid
 points in an X-domain sub-block.

Help.Tip: Number of sub-blocks in along the Y axis
Help.Text:
cpsmod - NY_BRICKS
Number of sub-blocks in along the Y axis
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer>=1
 The brick parameters allow the user to do a spatial domain decomposition of
 the calculation. The calculation for modeling or illumination is broken
 into sub-domains along the Y axis.

Help.Tip: Number of grid points that overlap along the Y axis
Help.Text:
cpsmod - BY_OVRLP
Number of grid points that overlap along the Y axis
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = Integer>=0
 The brick parameters allow the user to do a spatial domain decomposition of
 the calculation. The parameter ny_ovrlp controls the overlap between
 adjacent spatial block along the Y axis.
 This parameter is relevant to I3D only.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of grid points for a Y axis block
Help.Text:
cpsmod - BY_SIZ
Maximum number of grid points for a Y axis block
 
 Default = y_tot
 Allowed = Integer>0
 The brick parameters allow the user to do a spatial domain decomposition of
 the calculation. The parameter ny_siz indicates the maximum number of grid
 points in an Y-domain sub-block.

Help.Tip: Number of sub-blocks in along the Z axis
Help.Text:
cpsmod - NZ_BRICKS
Number of sub-blocks in along the Z axis
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = Integer>=1
 The brick parameters allow the user to do a spatial domain decomposition of
 the calculation. The calculation for modeling or illumination is broken
 into sub-domains along the Z axis.

Help.Tip: Number of grids overlap along the Z axis
Help.Text:
cpsmod - BZ_OVRLP
Number of grids overlap along the Z axis
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = Integer>=0
 The brick parameters allow the user to do a spatial domain decomposition of
 the calculation. The parameter nz_ovrlp controls the overlap between
 adjacent spatial block along the Y axis.
 This parameter is relevant to I3D only.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of grid points for a Z axis block
Help.Text:
cpsmod - BZ_SIZ
Maximum number of grid points for a Z axis block
 
 Default = z_tot
 Allowed = Integer>0
 The brick parameters allow the user to do a spatial domain decomposition of
 the calculation. The parameter nz_siz indicates the maximum number of grid
 points in an Z-domain sub-block.

Help.Tip: Press button to save a parameter file for the breakup program
Help.Text:
cpsmod - SAVE_BREAKUP_PARMS
Press button to save a parameter file for the breakup program
 
 Will create a file breakup_par.txt that is meant as input for the
 breakup program The breakup program will read in a model and create
 nx_bricks*ny_bricks sub-volumes.
 Using breakup to write the output models can take significant time for a
 large input model!

Help.Tip: Button that removes this process parameter screen.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - CLOSE
Button that removes this process parameter screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Appears only on the view-only process parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - CANCEL
Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - RESET
Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that sets the parameters back to their values when the screen appeared
 or to their last applied value.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PROCESSLISTLEFT
Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the previous process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PROCESSLIST
Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Menu that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to any chosen process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PROCESSLISTRIGHT
Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the next process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - PROJECTDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as Project Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of Project Defaults for a project.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - USERDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as User Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of User Defaults for a userid.

Help.Tip: Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
Help.Text:
cpsmod - HELP
Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 The Help Window allows access to three kinds of help:  Parameter Help, CPS
 Process Help and Application (CFE) Help.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         C P S   P R O C E S S
 
 Name       : CPSMOD
 Category   : SYNTHETICS
 Written    : 2004-09-30   by: R.S.Day
 Revised    : 2006-06-12   by: R.S.Day
 Maturity   : production
 Purpose    : Set modeling parameters for modeling programs
 Portability: No known limitations.
 Parallel   : No.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          GENERAL DESCRIPTION
 
 CPSMOD is a generic interface for modeling and illumination calculations. It
 allows the user to specify an acquisition geometry for sources and
 receievers with one interface. The parameters are converted by CPSMOD into
 application specific parameter file needed by a program (e.g. for A2D or E2D)
 The parameter files are written while CPSMOD is in GUI mode. CPSMOD will run
 the appropriate modeling program when the job is submitted to a queue.
 
 CPSMOD is a cps process that is setup only. That is to say, it invokes a
 modeling program at setup time and does not enter into any trace flows.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          ADVICE FOR USERS
 
 Some screen parameters are irrelevant for some modeling programs.For instance
 2D modeling generally ignores Y parameters that are in the 3rd dimension.
 
 When shot modeling one can specify source locations via a simple skip pattern
 or one can input the locations through a PATH_INFO file.
 
 The domain decomposition tab is used for large 3D calculations such as I3D or
 A3D. It is used to specify a block domain decomposition of a calculation.
 For I3D the decomposition devides the output into, generally overlapping,
 windows in the x-y plane. For A3D, A3D0, E3D the computation is broken
 into sub-domains that run on different.
 
 To maximize your effectiveness with CPSMOD, it is helpful to know something
 about FXINFO files from the FXINFO process and project files used by the
 TASKMAN process. These two file type are useful if you want to generate
 shots located at survey locations, and if one wants to run multiple jobs
 to generate more than a few shots.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                             REVISION HISTORY
 
     Date        Author     Description
     ----        ------     -----------
 14  2006-06-12  R.S.Day    Added SHOT_INC parameter for I3D option.
 13  2006-03-21  R.S.Day    Reformat output of I3D shell script.
 12  2006-03-14  R.S.Day    Fixed format problem with I3D parameter file
 11. 2006-02-23  R.S.Day    Corrected incorrect zero value of rotation angle.
 10. 2006-02-16  R.S.Day    Added save_breakup_parms button. Declared more
                            public functions.Added cpsmod_save_breakup.
                            Fix problem with file nameing convention.
  9. 2006-01-26  R.S.Day    Snapshot decimation added. Fixes for left handed
                            grid transforms.
  8. 2005-12-06  R.S.Day    Bricking support added for A3D, A3D0, I3D.
                            Fixed grid scaling problem in update.
                            Improved cpsmod_script_name. Added &
                            cpsmod_save_script_a3d, cpsmod_put_card,
                            cpsmod_put_jobbeg,cpsmod_put_jobend
                            cpsmod_get_task, cpsmod_siti_hdr,cpsmod_put_task,
                            Fix cpsmod_brick_work bug. Generate SITI hdrs.
  7. 2005-10-25  R.S.Day    Add support for A3D. Added sub-domain decomposition
                            for I3D and A3D. Fixed task file writing.
  6. 2005-08-23  R.S.Day    Make path_info always sensitive. Increase
                            max allowed size of source arrays.
  5. 2005-08-18  R.S.Day    Converted to parallel safe mode. All CPUs work.
                            Sensitivity changes. Delete unused variables.
                            Changes to I3D options.
  4. 2005-07-28  R.S.Day    Added support for SITI illumination - I3D
                            Additional GUI parameters for geometry description
  3. 2005-04-19  R.S.Day    A3D0 and I2D added
  2. 2004-12-09  R.S.Day    E2D modeling is enabled. Use amod module to input
                            anisotropic models.
  1. 2004-09-30  R.S.Day    Initial version.
